e.g.: keľgǝma lomań-ǝźǝ love-PTCP1 person-PX.1SG>3SG.NOM > keľgǝma-źǝ 'love-PTCP-PX.1SG>3SG 'my beloved (person)'; mora-f mor-ǝnzǝ sing-PTCP2.3SG>3PL  song-PX.3SG>3SG > moraf-ǝnzǝ 'the songs s/he sang'; sam-ǝz-ǝnzǝ come-ILL-PX.3SG>3SG 'until (s/he) comes_back'.

Peŕǝ-s;garden-INDF.ILL;into/up to a garden;

The ELA -stǝ/-ctǝ marking source: veď-stǝ 'out of the water', piľg-ctǝ 'out of, by the leg'; time: ńiľǝ-stǝ 'at four o'clock'; reference is marked by ABL: korxt-an keľ-ďǝ speak.PRS.1SG language-INDF.ABL.SG '(I) am talking about a language', śim-an veď-tǝ drink-PST1.1SG water-INDF.ABL.  'I am drinking (some) water'.

Translative -ks conveys the result of change: vasta-ś ťijǝv-ś mazi-ks place-DEF.NOM.SG become-PST1.3SG beautiful-INDF.NOM.TRA 'the place became beautiful'; ťijǝv-ś jońu lomań-eks (s/he) become-PST.3SG intelligent person.INDF.TRA.SG '(she) became an intelligent person.'
The comparative -ška: kemǝń-ška 'nearly, about ten; aľ-ǝnc eška father-PX.3SG>3SG. PP '(s/he is) of about father's height'.
The definite declension, which identifies the object in focus: oš 'a city, oš-ǝś 'the city'.

Non-singular possession is marked differently from SG possession: kud-ǝźǝ/-ǝńǝ house-PX.3SG>3SG.NOM/-PX.3SG>3PL.NOM 'my house/-s'. 10 cases: NOM, GEN, DAT, ABL, INE, ELA, ILL, PROL, COMP, ABE. Syncretic forms: non-singular possession (multiple possessor-multiple possessed) overlaps with (multiple possessor - singular possessed): jalga-n'kǝ/-n'ťǝ/-snǝ friend-PX.1/2/3PL>3SG/3PL 'our friend/-s'; e.g jalga-ńkǝ sa-ś friend-PX.1PL>3SG.NOM come-PST1.3SG 'our friend came', jalga-ńkǝ sa-śť friend-PX.1PL>3PL.NOM come-PST1.3PL 'our friens came.'
Meźǝ > meźǝ ťä?;;What is this?;|kijǝ > Kijǝ ťä?;;Who is this?;

The demonstrative pronouns ťä 'this', ńä-ťńä 'these, DEF', śä  'that', śä-tńä 'those, DEF' can be used independently: ťä  meźǝvǝk ašǝź juksta this.DEF.NOM anything-ACC.SG NEG forget-PRS.3SG 'This (one) did not forget anything.'

The main declension has only the PL marker (-t/-ť) in the NOM:  viŕx-ť 'forest-PL.' The DEF.SG and PL suffixes occur in NOM, GEN, DAT/ILL; the NOM, GEN, DAT/ILL.SG (-ś, -ť, -ťi) are added to the stem. In PL, the number/DEF marker -ťńǝ (NOM) is followed by the case marker: -ń (GEN), -ńďi (DAT): šuft-ťńǝ-ńďi 'to the trees'. The other cases are formed with postpositions: viŕx-ńǝń esa forest-GEN.PL + esa.PP 'in the woods'.
